ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: The class was a mix of live lecture and asynchronous classes.
Combination of synchronous and asynchronous approach.
Asynchronous learning
Asynchronous quizzes/homework
3 synchronous days, 2 asynchronous days
A combination of synchronous and asynchronous classes throughout the week, normally alternating between the two with the first one Monday/Wednesday/Friday and the latter on Tuesday/Thursday.
Asynchronous work on days with no zoom.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I sharpened my skills on the Spanish language. I improved my speaking and reading skills.  Yale has some of the best Spanish classes in the United States. The Spanish department at Yale know what they are doing!
My vocabulary and comfort speaking and listening all improved over the course of this class.
Important Spanish speaking and writing skills
I now have a much better aural, oral and reading comprehension of Spanish
I definitely developed my Spanish speaking and comprehension ability, as well as my writing ability and bredth as we learned new tenses this semester.
Better spanish speaking skills, new and better grammar, and better writing.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths- Dr. Daz is the best professor that I have had at Yale. He knows how to teach, he is a nice guy, and he cares about his student's success. He wants to see his students learn the language, and that really makes all the difference. Thank you Dr. Daz! 

Weakness- Some of the assignments were a bit unclear and the due dates were a bit shady. However, the course was taught perfectly and all the exams were fair and graded fairly.

strengths: lots of practice both on your own and with others
weaknesses: a lot of work was assigned that was never gone over, so it was hard to learn from doing it since you never knew when you made mistakes, there were a lot of additional things on canvas on top of what was on the syllabus, so it was difficult to figure out what needed to be done, the constant breakout rooms during class got monotonous and I think we could have benefited from more variety in learning

Overall the focus of the class on actually practicing Spanish and listening was useful. I thought more of a focus on Hispanic culture would have been helpful to contextualize the language more. Additionally, the administration of some important assignments was quite clunky. I regularly felt deprived of the full time allotted for quizzes and exams and considering that many of the exams were difficult (excessively so in my opinion) to finish within the time provided it was quite a challenge to lose 3-5 minutes at the beginning of classes.
The syllabus was very detailed but somehow unclear. There was a plethora of material which is helpful but overwhelming.

While certainly different online, I liked how Prof. Diaz handled this course. Not having synchronous classes every day of the week was helpful in managing my time and being able to learn at my own pace and review other material I needed to. While there would sometimes be confusion on what assignments were due when, a quick email to Prof. Diaz would always quickly clear that up and having a section group chat was also great to make sure you were on the same page as everyone. In all definitely a good course to improve your Spanish and I thought Prof. Diaz was good in the online format.
It could be improved with less quizzes about readings, although a strength is wrapping information from multiple lessons into the tests.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I am glad that they cut down the live lecture days to only three times a week. Logging on to Zoom 5 days a week is a bit tedious. I would advise to continue this for next semester.

Almost everything went quite well considering the circumstances. As I said, tests and quizzes require some improvement and I believe they should be shortened in their length or we need to be alotted more time in order for them to be fair and accurate assessments of our knowledge over the virtual format

It was definitely harded for me to practice speaking with the online format, but signing up for the tutoring sessions really helped out with that. Other then that I felt my reading and writing ability greatly improved this semester and the online format made that possible with the synchronous and asynchronous classes.
Having mandatory class with a small group of students was a good practice.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. Spanish L3 was my favorite of all three Spanish classes. This is a good class for those actually wanting to be able to speak basic Spanish. Also, take it with Dr. Sebastian Daz if you can, I love him!

I'm not sure if this is caused by the move online or if this is normal for L3, but as the class is, I don't think I would recommend it. It felt a lot less organized than L1 and L2 spanish and generally more overwhelming due to that lack of clear organization.
Yes, if a student has an interest in learning Spanish they should at least reach this level of the program.
If they need to finish the requirement

Yes. Prof. Diaz is great and a wonderful person. He was very helpful. The course as a whole is like any other spanish course and I think most people take it as a requirement. You learn new tenses and practice your writing ability and there are no curveballs. Would recommend Prof Diaz.
Yes, overall my spanish is improved.
